content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The Maclaurin series for a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="f of x, equals, x minus, the fraction x cubed, over 3 factorial, end fraction, plus the fraction x to the fifth power, over 5 factorial, end fraction, minus the fraction x to the seventh power, over 7 factorial, end fraction, plus, dot dot dot, plus the fraction with numerator open parenthesis, negative 1, close parenthesis, to the n power, times x raised to the 2 n plus 1, power, and denominator open parenthesis 2 n plus 1, close parenthesis, factorial, end fraction, plus, dot dot dot"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mo>⋯</mo><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mo>⋯</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and converges to <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for all <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals, f of, open parenthesis, x squared, close parenthesis"><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

(a)   Find the first four nonzero terms and the general term of the Maclaurin series for <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The Maclaurin series for a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="f of x, equals, x minus, the fraction x cubed, over 3 factorial, end fraction, plus the fraction x to the fifth power, over 5 factorial, end fraction, minus the fraction x to the seventh power, over 7 factorial, end fraction, plus, dot dot dot, plus the fraction with numerator open parenthesis, negative 1, close parenthesis, to the n power, times x raised to the 2 n plus 1, power, and denominator open parenthesis 2 n plus 1, close parenthesis, factorial, end fraction, plus, dot dot dot"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mo>⋯</mo><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mo>⋯</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and converges to <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for all <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals, f of, open parenthesis, x squared, close parenthesis"><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

(a)   Find the first four nonzero terms and the general term of the Maclaurin series for <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b)   Find <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 0, of, the complex fraction with numerator x squared, minus the fraction x to the sixth power, over 6, end fraction, minus, g of x, and denominator x to the tenth power, end complex fraction"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c)   Let <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x, equals, the integral from 0 to x, of, g of t, d t"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write the first four nonzero terms and the general term of the Maclaurin series for <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the first two terms of your answer to approximate <math alttext="h of 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d)   Explain why the approximation found in part (c) differs from the actual value of <math alttext="h of 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> by less than <math alttext="the fraction 1 over 1000"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1000</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 10.1: (BC ONLY) Defining Convergent and Divergent Infinite Series

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Identify a re-expression of mathematical information presented in a given representation
